description: Evidence that implies a fact but does not directly prove it, relying on inference to connect it to a conclusion. Examples include fingerprints at a crime scene or a defendant being seen fleeing an area.
Tangible items, substances, or material objects that can be used to prove a fact or link a defendant to a crime. Examples include weapons, fingerprints, DNA samples, or damaged property.
Written or recorded materials used to prove a point in court. Examples include contracts, emails, medical records, and financial statements.
Statements made under oath by witnesses, experts, or involved parties, either in court or in out-of-court depositions. It is a primary form of evidence in both civil and criminal cases.
Testimony, opinions, or analysis offered by qualified experts in a specific field to help the court understand complex issues or scientific evidence.
Evidence that is not from the crime scene itself but illustrates or demonstrates a concept to the trier of fact. Examples include charts, diagrams, and anatomical models.
Information stored or transmitted in binary form that may be relied on in court. This includes data from computers, mobile phones, social media, and other electronic sources.

Also known as scientific evidence, it is derived from the application of scientific methods to legal questions. This includes DNA matching, fingerprint identification, hair and fiber analysis, and ballistics.

Evidence of a person's character or character trait, offered to prove that on a particular occasion the person acted in accordance with the character or trait. Its admissibility is highly restricted by rules of evidence.
An out-of-court statement offered to prove the truth of the matter asserted. It is generally inadmissible in court unless it falls under a specific exception provided by the rules of evidence.
Any type of evidence that tends to reduce a defendant's culpability or clear them of guilt. Prosecutors are legally required to disclose exculpatory evidence to the defense.
